Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Contribution of Polyamines to N and C cycling in Marine Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
While dissolved organic nitrogen (DON) plays a central role in global ocean N cycling, little is known about specific DON components. To address one aspect of this, investigators from Kent State University and the University of Georgia will examine polyamines, an under-studied microbially-produced DON component. They hypothehesize that, despite the low concentrations of these N-rich compounds, free polyamines have an important role in microbial ecology. To test this hypothesis, the investigators will examine the concentration, flux and fate of dissolved polyamines and dissolved amino acids at nearshore and open ocean sites using various chemical analyses. The composition of bacterial assemblages and of genes involved in polyamine utilization will also be determined using state-of-the-art molecular techniques. By integrating biogeochemical and molecular approaches, and linking functional genomics
of plankton assemblages to material fluxes, the work will improve the understanding of the fate and dynamics of DON in marine environments, and the importance of polyamines as sources of C and N. This collaborative project will
enhance inter-institution partnerships, and train graduate students while also
reaching out to under-represented and promising first- and
second-year undergraduate and high school students. The students will be involved with research opportunities, summer internships, and other activities.

Most of the nitrogen present in coastal waters is in the form of nitrogen-containing organic matter. This is a poorly characterized mixture of compounds that range in bioavailability from inert to easily metabolized. The purpose of this project was to investigate the biological and chemical cycling of one such group of organic nitrogen compounds, the polyamines. Polyamines are closely related small molecules consisting of 2 or more nitrogen atoms linked to 3-8 carbon atoms. They are found in all cells at concentrations comparable to amino acids. Unlike amino acids, whose role is primarily to serve as building blocks for proteins, polyamines serve to stabilize biological structures, and in particular the structure of DNA. Because they are important to the biochemistry of cells and used in large quantities, microorganisms have evolved highly efficient systems for recovering them from the environment, which is energetically cheaper than synthesizing them from raw materials. However, the few previous studies of polyamine dynamics yielded conflicting results. Some of this uncertainty may be due to differences in analytical techniques, some to differences in the composition of microbial communities using the polyamines, and some of it may reflect uncoupling between polyamine supply and demand. The overall goals of this project were to evaluate the relative merit of each of these explanations; to identify the sources and sinks of polyamines; and to estimate their contribution to the nitrogen dynamics of a coastal ecosystem. We performed the studies in Georgia coastal waters because previous work there had characterized the microbial communities and shown that they were actively producing the proteins needed to use polyamines. The area is also the site of monitoring programs by State and Federal agencies so we had the benefit of the data they collected as a context for our work. We adapted a technique from food science that enabled us to detect polyamines at the very low concentrations found in the environment (a few billionths of a gram per liter). Our measurements told us that polyamine concentrations are typically 1/10th those of amino acids, suggesting greater demand for them by the microbial community and highly efficient uptake systems. Polyamine concentrations were higher nearshore than offshore and polyamine concentrations covaried with estimates of plant biomass. We identified 5 different polyamines (and 20 different amino acids) in our samples and observed that the composition of the polyamine pool varied from site to site and with time. ...
